nodes.text: A quantum propensity framework, inspired by quantum computing, can model economic decision-making and financial transactions more consistently than classical utility-based approaches by representing decisions as probabilistic propensity functions that permit interference and entanglement effects

Classical neoclassical economics assumes rational utility-maximizers with stable preferences driving markets to equilibrium, but empirical cognitive phenomena (e.g., preference reversal, order effect, disjunction effect) violate these assumptions

Quantum probability uses the 2-norm and complex amplitudes, enabling superposition, interference, and entanglement, making it suitable to capture nonclassical decision behaviors observed in social sciences
Decision-makers can be modeled by a propensity function giving the probability of transacting or choosing, replacing the classical utility function

A simple two-qubit quantum circuit with rotation gates A and B and a C-NOT gate can simulate sequences of decisions and contextual effects, producing the same joint probabilities as sequential projections used in quantum cognition

The quantum circuit reproduces specific cognitive phenomena: order effects (different answer probabilities depending on question order), the disjunction effect, and preference reversal via interference and entanglement

A given propensity function (e.g., normal distribution over log price) can be interpreted as the squared amplitude of an underlying quantum wavefunction, allowing a quantized representation of continuous economic choices

Propensity curves for buyer and seller multiply to yield a joint propensity; only regions near the mid-price are active in transactions, and fixed-price sellers can be modeled as infinitely narrow propensity curves

Equivalence between one-qubit sequential measurement models and the two-qubit circuit is shown: arbitrary unitary gates A and B produce matching final outcome probabilities, demonstrating circuit flexibility

Interpreting propensity via a quantum harmonic oscillator links propensity variance to an associated mass m = hbar/(2 omega sigma squared) and defines an energy scaling gamma = hbar omega squared, giving consistent physical-like units to economic dynamics

The entropic force f(x) = gamma P'(x)/P(x) yields linear spring-like forces for normal propensities (f(x) = -k(x-mu)) and allows computing information or work required to change mental states between prices as Delta E = gamma log(P(x2)/P(x1))

Threshold effects arise: empirical preference reversal criterion shows a switch from more to less attractive option occurs when cost ratio x2/x1 > 3, corresponding in the model to an energy change on the order of the base quantum oscillator energy

The quantum propensity framework can model financial market features (non-normal distributions, option pricing, return mean reversion speed via oscillator frequency) and simulate economic phenomena driven by information flow

Adopting propensity and quantum probability allows expressing supply and demand forces, subjective and objective factors, and power relationships in consistent units, offering a unified quantitative framework for economic dynamics

Limitations and assumptions include mapping social motivations to quantized propensities, treating mental states probabilistically, and relying on analogies from physics which may not capture all social complexity

Overall conclusion: quantum economics reframes value from utility to propensity, and the proposed quantum propensity approach provides a consistent mathematical framework to incorporate cognitive interference, entanglement, dynamics, and information-based forces in economics and finance
